Proof of Lemma 7.5

We start with a key observation.

Lemma 7.6.

Consider an arbitrary pair of functions s1,s2:Ω→{1,…,m} that take as input a state σ and output an index in U(σ). Let i≁j be two arbitrary indices in {1,…,m}. Then, for every pair of states σ1,σ2∈Ω we have that Ai,s1Aj,s2[σ1,σ2]≤Aj,pjAi,pi[σ1,σ2].

Proof.
Ai,s1Aj,s2[σ1,σ2]≤∑σ∈A(i,σ1)ρi(σ1,σ)ρj(σ,σ2)=∑σ∈A(j,σ1)ρj(σ1,σ)ρi(σ,σ2)=Aj,pjAi,pi[σ1,σ2].

where the first equality holds because AiAj=AjAj (since i≁j) and the second equality holds by the definitions of pi,pj. ∎

Let W∗=(w∗1,w∗2,…,w∗i−1,w∗i,…) and define A(W∗)⊆W to be the set of witnesses that will be affected by Swap, i.e., the set of witnesses whose (i−1)-th and i-th elements are w∗i−1 and w∗i, respectively. Finally, let IA(W∗) be the subset of W′ that is the image of A(W∗). We consider two cases.

In the first case, we assume that the mapping from W to W′ is bijective. Given a witness sequence W=(w1,…,w∗i−1,w∗i,…,wt)∈A(W∗), let W′=(w1,…,w∗i,w∗i−1,…,wt)∈IA(W∗) be the corresponding witness according to the bijection. By Lemma 7.6 and the definition of S′ we obtain

∥∥θ⊤Aw1,s1…Awi−1,si−1Awi,si…∥∥1≤∥∥θ⊤Aw1,s1…Awi,pwiAwi−1,pwi−1…∥∥1,

which concludes the proof for this case.

In the second case, the mapping from W to W′ is not bijective. Observe that this can only be the case when there exist pairs (W1,W2)∈W of the form

W1 = (w1,w2,…,w∗i−1,w∗i,…,wt);
W2 = (w1,w2,…,w∗i,w∗i−1,…,wt),

in which case W1 is mapped to W2. Thus, it suffices to show that

∥∥θ⊤Aw1,s1…(Aw∗i−1,si−1Aw∗i,si+Aw∗i,si−1Aw∗i−1,si)…Awt,st∥∥1≤
∥∥∥θ⊤Aw1,s1…Aw∗i,pw∗iAw∗i−1,pw∗i−1…Awt,st∥∥∥1. (40)

To prove (40) it suffices to show that

Aw∗i−1,si−1Aw∗i,si[σ,σ′]+Aw∗i,si−1Aw∗i−1,si[σ,σ′]≤Aw∗i,p∗wiAw∗i−1,pw∗i−1[σ,σ′], (41)

for each pair of states (σ,σ′). If si−1(σ)∉{w∗i−1,w∗i}, then (41) is trivially true. If, on the other hand, si−1(σ)∈{w∗i−1,w∗i}, then either si−1(σ)=w∗i and Aw∗i−1,si−1Aw∗i,si[σ,σ′]=0, or si−1(σ)=w∗i−1 and Aw∗i,si−1Aw∗i−1,si[σ,σ′]=0. The proof of (41) in the first case follows immediately by the definitions of pwi−1,pwi and in the second case from Lemma 7.6.

Appendix A Comparison to Previous Algorithmic LLL Criteria

Recall that, by definition, γ∅i≥γSi, for all S⊆[m]. To lighten notation, we write γ∅i=γi.

a.1 Uniform Random Walks [3]

If we take M=I/|Ω|, then γi=∥Ai∥. In [3], addressing a flaw fi at σ∈fi always amounts to choosing uniformly among the available actions for doing so. Let Di be the digraph on Ω corresponding to the non-zero entries of Ai. To bound ∥Ai∥1 observe that the 1-norm of each column σ′ is bounded by Indegi(σ′)× the largest entry in column σ′. Since actions are always chosen uniformly, if that largest entry occurs in row σ it must equal 1/Outdegi(σ). Therefore, we see that (1) recovers (and sharpens) the condition of [3], since

γi=∥MAiM−1∥1≤max(σ,σ′)∈DiIndegi(σ′)Outdegi(σ)≤maxσIndegi(σ)minσOutdegi(σ).

a.2 Resampling Oracles [32]

The resampling oracles formulation of Harvey and Vondrák [32] requires that for every flaw fi, the transition probabilities ρi are such that for every σ′∈Ω,

1μ(fi)∑σ∈fiμ(σ)ρi(σ,σ′)=μ(σ′). (42)

One can interpret (42) as requiring the following: if σ∈fi is sampled according to μ and flaw fi is addressed at σ, then the resulting state σ′ should be distributed exactly according to μ, i.e., addressing fi should perfectly remove the conditional of the state having been in fi. For example, if μ is a product measure, this is precisely what is achieved by the resampling algorithm of Moser and Tardos [41].

Taking M=diag(μ(σ)) we see that (1) recovers the condition of [32], since, by (42),

γi=∥MAiM−1∥1=maxσ′∈Ω1μ(σ′)∑σ∈fiμ(σ)ρi(σ,σ′)=μ(fi).

a.3 Approximate Oracles [2, 37]

As discussed in the introduction, the charge of each flaw in [2, 37] equals γi=γ∅i=∥MAiM−1∥1≥μ(fi), where the last inequality is due to the fact (42) need not hold. Allowing for actions and transition probabilities that distort the measure μ in the above experiment, so that γi=diμ(fi) for some distortion factor di>1, can pay off by making the dependency graph sparser. As shown in [2, 37], when the dependency graph is undirected, one can generalize (1) to the cluster expansion criterion [14] and Shearer’s criterion [46].

a.4 This Paper: Point to Set Correlations

When M=diag(μ(σ)) and ∥⋅∥=∥⋅∥1, we see that for an arbitrary set S,

γSi=∥MASiM−1∥1=(maxσ′∈ΩνSi(σ′)μ(σ))μ(fi),

where νSi(σ′) is the the probability of reaching state σ′ in the aforementioned experiment via a transition that introduced every flaw in S (and perhaps more). Thus, in this case, Theorem 3.1 is a refinement of the notion of distortion by the algorithm of the probability measure μ.

Appendix B Proofs Omitted from Section 6

In this section we show the proof of Lemma 6.4

b.1 Proof of Lemma 6.4

Our computations are similar to the ones in [38]. The following version of Chernoff Bounds will be useful:

Lemma B.1.

If {Xi}mi=1∈{0,1} are negatively correlated and X=∑mi=1Xi, then for any 0<t≤E[X],

Pr[|X−E[X]|>t]<2exp(−t23E[X]).
Proof of part (a).

Let v∈V and σ∈Ω be arbitrary and let σ′∈Ω be the (random) output (state) of Recolor(v,σ). For each color c∈Lv, let Pcv={u∈Nv:c∈Rvu(σ)} and define

ρ(c)=∑u∈Pcv1|Rvu(σ)|−1.

Since c∈Rvu(σ) implies |Rvu(σ)|≥2, and since 1−1/x>exp(−1/(x−1)) for x≥2, we see that

E[|Lv(σ′)|]=1+∑c∈Lv∏u∈Pcv(1−1|Rvu(σ)|)>∑c∈Lv∏u∈Pcvexp(−1|Rvu(σ)|−1)=∑c∈Lve−ρ(c). (43)

Also, since each Rvu(σ) has |Rvu(σ)|−1 non-Blank colors, we see that

Zv:=∑c∈Lvρ(c)≤∑u∈Nv∑c∈Rvu(σ)∖Blank1|Rvu(σ)|−1≤Δ. (44)

The fact that e−x is convex implies that the right hand side of (43) is at least |Lv|exp(−Zv/|Lv|). Recalling that |Lv|=q=(1+ϵ)Δln√f and combining (43) with (44) yields

E[|Lv(σ′)|]>qe−Zv/q≥(1+ϵ)Δln√fe−Δ/q=2(1+ϵ)Δlnff−12(1+ϵ)=2L.

Let Xc be the indicator variable that c∈Lv(σ′) so that |Lv(σ′)|=1+∑c∈Lv(σ′)Xc. It is not hard to see that the variables Xc are negatively correlated, so that applying Lemma B.1 with t=12E[|Lv(σ′)|]>L yields

Pr[|Lv(σ′)|<12E[|Lv(σ′)|]]≤2e−E[|Lv(σ′)|]/12<2e−L/6.

∎

Proof of part (b).

Let Ψ={c∈Lv(σ):ρ(c)≥L/20}∖Blank. The probability that Lv(σ′) contains at least one color from Ψ is at most

E[|Lv(σ′)∩Ψ|]=∑c∈Ψ∏u∈Pcv(1−1|Rvu(σ)|)<∑c∈Ψ∏u∈Pcvexp(−12(|Rvu(σ)|−1))<∑c∈Ψe−ρ(c)/2,

where we used that c∈Rvu(σ) implies |Rvu(σ)|≥2, and that 1−1/x<exp(−1/(2(x−1))) for x≥2. Finally note that ∑c∈Ψe−ρ(c)/2≤qe−L/40 by the definition of the set Ψ.

Recall that Tv,c(σ′)={u∈Nv:σ′(u)=Blank % and c∈Lu(σ′)}. Since Lu(σ′)⊆Ru(σ′)=Ru(σ), it follows that Tv,c(σ′)⊆Pcv and, therefore, E[|Tv,c(σ′)|]≤∑u∈Pcv1/|Rvu(σ)|≤ρ(c). Since the vertices in Pcv are colored (and thus become Blank) independently and since ρ(c)<L/20 for c∉Ψ, applying Lemma B.1 with t=L/20 yields Pr[|Tv,c(σ′)|>E[|Tv,c(σ′)|]+L/20]<2e−L/60. Applying the union bound over all q colors, we see that the probability there is at least one c∉Ψ for which |Tv,c(σ′)|>L/10 is at most 2qe−L/60. Thus, with probability at least 1−3qe−L/60,

∑c∈Lv(σ′)∖Blank|Tv,c(σ′)|=∑c∈Lv(σ′)∖(Ψ∪Blank)|Tv,c(σ′)|<L10|Lv(σ′)|.

∎

Appendix C Proof of Theorem 3.2

The second part of Theorem 3.2, concerning the case f≥Δ2+2ϵ1+2ϵ(lnΔ)2, follows immediately from Theorem 3.4, since χ(G)≤χℓ(G), for every graph G. To prove the first part, i.e., for arbitrary f≥fϵ, we will follow closely the approach adopted by the authors in [7]. Throughout the proof we assume that ϵ∈(0,ϵ0), where ϵ0 is sufficiently small, and that fϵ>0 and Δϵ>0 are sufficiently large.

We distinguish two cases, depending on whether f≥Δ(2+ϵ2)ϵ or not. To prove Theorem 3.2 for the case f≥Δ(2+ϵ2)ϵ we will prove the following.

Theorem C.1.

For every θ,ζ∈(0,1), there exists Δθ,ζ>0 such that every graph G with maximum degree Δ≥Δθ,ζ in which the neighbors of every vertex span at most Δ2−(2+ζ)θ edges, has chromatic number χ(G)≤(1+ζ)(1+θ−1)ΔlnΔ.

Proof of Theorem 3.2 for f≥Δ(2+ϵ2)ϵ.

We apply Theorem C.1 with ζ=ϵ2 and θ=lnf(2+ϵ2)lnΔ≥ϵ, so that Δ2/f=Δ2−(2+ζ)θ. Since ζ,θ<1, we obtain

χ(G) ≤ (1+ζ)(1+(2+ζ)lnΔlnf)ΔlnΔ
= (1+ζ)ΔlnΔ+(1+ζ)(1+ζ/2)Δln√f
≤ (1+2ζ)Δln√f+(1+ζ)(1+ζ/2)Δln√f
= (2+7ζ2+ζ22)Δln√f
≤ (2+ϵ)Δln√f.

∎

Theorem C.1 follows immediately from the following lemma, whose proof is similar to Lemma 2.3 in [7] and can be found in Section C.1. The proof of Lemma C.2 uses the standard Local Lemma and Theorem 3.4, so it can be made constructive using the Moser-Tardos algorithm and the algorithm in Theorem 3.4.

Lemma C.2.

For every θ,ζ∈(0,1) there exists Δθ,ζ>0 such that for every graph G=(V,E) with maximum degree Δ≥Δθ,ζ in which the neighbors of every vertex span at most Δ2−(2+ζ)θ edges, there exists a partition of the vertex set V=V1∪…∪Vk with k=Δ1−θ, such that for every 1≤i≤k,

χ(G[Vi])≤(1+ζ)(1+θ−1)ΔθlnΔ.
Proof of Theorem c.1.

If V1,V2,…,Vk, k=Δ1−θ is the partition promised by Lemma C.2 then

χ(G)≤Δ1−θ∑i=1χ(G[Vi])≤(1+ζ)(1+θ−1)ΔlnΔ.

∎

To prove Theorem 3.2 for f∈[fϵ,Δ(2+ϵ2)ϵ), we will perform a sequence of random halving steps, as in [7], to partition the graph into subgraphs satisfying the condition of Theorem 3.2 with f≥Δ(2+ϵ2)ϵ and color these subgraphs using disjoint sets of colors. To perform the partition we use the following lemma from [7]. As it is proven via the standard LLL, it can be made constructive using the Moser-Tardos algorithm.

Lemma C.3 ([7]).

Let G(V,E) be a graph with maximum degree Δ≥2 in which the neighbors of every vertex span at most s edges. There exists a partition V=V1∪V2 such that the induced subgraph G[Vi],i=1,2, has maximum degree at most Δ/2+2√ΔlnΔ and the neighborhors of every vertex in G[Vi],i=1,2, span at most s/4+2Δ32√lnΔ edges.

We will also use the following lemma whose proof, presented in Section C.2, is almost identical to a similar statement in the proof of Theorem 1.1 of [7].

Lemma C.4.

Given Δ,f sufficiently large, let the sequences Δt and st be defined as follows. Δ0=Δ,s0=Δ2/f and

Δt+1=Δt/2+2√ΔtlnΔt,st+1=st/4+2Δ32t√lnΔt.

For any δ∈(0,1/100) and ζ>0 such that ζ(2+δ)<1/10, let j be the smallest integer for which f>((1+δ)Δ2j)(2+δ)ζ. Then Δj≤(1+δ)Δ/2j and sj≤((1+δ)Δ/2j)2/f.

Proof of Theorem 3.2 for f∈[fϵ,Δ(2+ϵ2)ϵ).

Let ϵ0=1/11. For ϵ∈(0,ϵ0], let δ=ζ=ϵ2. Since ζ(2+δ)<1/10, apply Lemma C.4 and let j=j(Δ,f,δ,ζ) be the integer described therein. Let S be the process which, given a graph G, does nothing if Δ(G)<2, and otherwise partitions G as described in Lemma C.3. Apply S to G to get subgraphs G[V1],G[V2]. Apply S to G[V1],G[V2] to get G[V1,1],G[V1,2],G[V2,1],G[V2,2]. And so on, j times, obtaining a partition of G into at most 2j induced subgraphs. Observe that for each such subgraph H, either Δ(G)<2 and, thus, χ(H)≤2, or, by Lemma C.4, Δ(H)≤(1+δ)Δ/2j=:Δ∗ and the neighbors of every vertex in H span at most Δ2∗/f edges, where f≥Δ(2+δ)ζ∗=Δ(2+ζ)ζ∗≥Δ(2+ζ2)ζ∗. Therefore, by the already established case of Theorem 3.2, either χ(H)≤2, or χ(H)≤(2+ζ)Δ∗/ln√f. Thus,

χ(G)≤2jmax{2,(2+ζ)(1+δ)Δ/2jln√f}≤max{2j+1,(2+ζ)(1+δ)Δln√f}.

To bound 2j+1 from above we first observe that for all f sufficiently large, i.e., for all f≥fϵ,

⎛⎜ ⎜⎝(1+δ)ΔΔ2ln√f⎞⎟ ⎟⎠(2+δ)ζ=(2(1+δ)ln√f)(2+δ)ζ<f. (45)

Now, since j was defined as the smallest integer for which ((1+δ)Δ2j)(2+δ)ζ<f, we see that (45) implies 2j≤Δ2ln√f and, therefore, 2j+1≤Δln√f. Finally, we observe that (2+ζ)(1+δ)=(2+ϵ2)(1+ϵ2)<2+ϵ for all ϵ∈(0,ϵ0]. Therefore, as claimed,

χ(G)≤(2+ϵ)Δln√f.

∎

c.1 Proof of Lemma c.2

We follow an approach similar to the one of Lemma 2.3 in [7] making appropriate modifications as needed. First we partition the vertices of G into Δ1−θ parts by coloring them randomly and independently with Δ1−θ colors. For a vertex v and a neighbor u adjacent to it, call u a bad neighbor of v, if u and v have at least Δ1−(1+ζ/2)θ common neighbors. Otherwise, say that u is a good neighbor. Since the neighbors of every vertex span at most Δ2−(2+ζ)θ edges, there are at most 2Δ1−(1+ζ/2)θ bad neighbors for any vertex in G.

For any vertex v, define three types of bad event with respect to the random partitioning experiment.

  • Av: more than (1+θ)Δθ neighbors of v receive the same color as v.

  • Bv: more than 10θζ bad neighbors of v receive the same color as v.

  • Cv: the good neighbors of v that receive the same color as v span more than 100(θζ)2 edges.

We will use the symmetric version of the Local Lemma [20] to show that we can find a coloring of the graph that avoids all bad events. First, note that each of the bad events Av,Bv,Cv is independent of all but at most Δ2 others, as it independent of all events Au,Bu,Cu corresponding to vertices u whose distance from v is more than 2. Since the degree of any vertex in its colors class is binomially distributed with mean at most Δθ, standard Chernoff estimates imply that the probability that v has more than (1+θ)Δθ neighbors of the same color as that of v is at most e−Ω(Δθ), which means that Pr[Av]<Δ−3 for large enough Δ. Moreover, we also have

Pr[Bv]≤(2Δ1−(1+ζ/2)θ10θζ)(1Δ1−θ)10θζ≤⎛⎝2Δθζ2⎞⎠10θζ≤Δ−3,

for large enough Δ. Finally, to bound the probability of Cv we make the following observation. If a graph has at least e2 edges, then either it has a vertex of degree at least e, or every vertex has degree strictly less than e, implying that the graph can be edge-colored with ⌈e⌉ colors, in which case the largest color class must contain at least e2/⌈e⌉≥e−1 edges. Thus, a graph with more than 100/(θζ)2 edges either has a vertex of degree at least 10/(θζ)≥9/(θζ) or a matching with at least 10/(θζ)−1≥9/(θζ) edges, where the inequality follows from the fact that θ,ζ<1. Thus, Cv can happen only if there is a good neighbor u of v such that u and v have at least 9/(θζ) common neighbors with the same color as v, or if there is a matching of size at least 9/(θζ) on the good neighbors of v that have the same color as v. The probabilities of the first and second of these events are bounded, respectively, by

Δ(Δ1−(1+ζ/2)θ9θζ)(1Δ1−θ)9θζ≤⎛⎝1Δθζ2⎞⎠9θζ≤12Δ−3,
(Δ2−(2+ζ)θ9θζ)((1Δ1−θ)2)9θζ≤(1Δθζ)9θζ≤12Δ−3.

Therefore the probability of Cv is at most Δ−3. Thus, the Local Lemma applies since each bad event has probability at most Δ−3 and is independent of all but at most Δ2 other bad events. This means that we can find a partition V=V1,…,Vk, where k=Δ1−θ, so that in each induced subgraph G[Vi], every vertex: has degree at most (1+θ)Δθ, has at most 10θζ bad neighbors, and is contained in at most 100(θζ)2 triangles in which both other vertices are good. We will show that, given such a partition, each G[Vi] can be colored with at most (1+ζ)(1+θ−1)ΔθlnΔ colors, assuming Δ is large enough.

To see this, consider the partition Bi,Vi∖Bi of Vi, where Bi is the set of vertices u∈Vi for which there exists a vertex v∈Vi, such that u is a bad neighbor of v. We claim that χ(G[Bi])≤20θζ+1 and χ(G[Vi∖Bi])≤(1+ζ/2)(1+θ−1)ΔθlnΔ. Assuming this claim, observe that

χ(G[Vi])≤20θζ+1+(1+ζ/2)(1+θ−1)ΔθlnΔ≤(1+ζ)(1+θ−1)ΔθlnΔ,

where the last inequality holds for all Δ≥Δθ,ζ.

To see the first part of the claim, note that it is well-known (and easy to see) that if a graph has an orientation with maximum outdegree d, then it is (2d+1)-colorable. Consider the orientation of the graph on Bi that results when every vertex points to its bad neighbors in Bi. Clearly, the maximum outdegree is at most 10θζ and, thus, χ(G[Bi])≤20θζ+1 .

To see the second part of the claim, observe that each vertex of G[Vi∖Bi] is contained in at most 100(θζ)2 triangles. Let Δ∗=(1+θ)Δθ and

f=((1+θ)Δθ)2100/(θζ)2=(θζ)2Δ2∗100≥Δ2+2ζ31+2ζ3∗(lnΔ∗)2,

where the last inequality holds for Δ≥Δθ,ζ. Applying Theorem 3.4 to G[Vi∖Bi] (by plugging in ζ/3 for the ϵ in Theorem 3.4 ) we get that, for all Δ≥Δθ,ζ,

χℓ(G[Vi∖Bi]) ≤ (1+ζ/3)Δ∗ln√f
= (1+ζ/3)(1+θ)Δθln(1+θ)θζΔθ10
= (1+ζ/3)(1+θ)ΔθθlnΔ+ln(1+θ)θζ10
≤ (1+ζ/2)(1+θ)θΔθlnΔ
= (1+ζ/2)(1+θ−1)ΔθlnΔ,

as claimed.

c.2 Proof of Lemma c.4

Let ϵ′:=ζ(2+δ) and recall that ϵ′<110 by hypothesis. By the definition of j, for every t<j,

Δt≥Δ/(2t)>f1ϵ′1+δ,

and f1ϵ′/(1+δ) can be made arbitrarily large by taking f to be sufficiently large. Hence, we can assume that Δt is sufficiently large in order for Δt+1≤Δt2+Δ23t≤12(Δ13t+1)3 to hold. Taking cube roots and subtracting 1213−1 from both sides we get

Δ13t+1−1213−1≤1213(Δ13t+1)−1213−1=1213⎛⎝Δ13t−1213−1⎞⎠.

Therefore,

Δ13j−1213−1≤12j/3⎛⎝Δ130−1213−1⎞⎠. (46)

Since Δ0=Δ, 213−1>14 and Δ/2j−1>f1ϵ′1+δ is large enough, (46) implies that

Δ13j≤Δ132j/3+4≤(1+δ)13Δ132j/3.

Therefore, we have shown that Δj≤(1+δ)Δ2j. Note also that the same proof shows that for every t≤j we have that Δt≤(1+δ)Δ2t.

We turn now to the claim regarding sj. For all t<j, we have by definition

st≥s04t=Δ24tf=1(1+δ)2((1+δ)Δ2t)2f≥1(1+δ)2((1+δ)Δ2t)2−ϵ′≥1(1+δ)2Δ2−ϵ′t, (47)

where in the last inequality we used the fact that Δt≤(1+δ)Δ2t for all t≤j. Using (47) to bound Δt in the expression that defines st, we get

st+1≤st4+2((1+δ)2st)321(2−2ϵ′). (48)

To bound the r.h.s. of (48) we recall that ϵ′<110 implying 32(2−2ϵ′)<32(2−1/5)=5/6. Assuming that f (and, thus, Δt) is large enough, we obtain

st+1≤st4+3s5/6t≤14(s1/6t+2)6=14(st+12s5/6t+60s2/3t+⋯). (49)

Hence, taking 6-th roots and subtracting 561/6−1 from both sides, we obtain

s1/6t+1−561/6−1≤141/6(s1/6t+2)−561/6−1≤141/6(s1/6t−561/6−1).

Therefore

s1/6j−561/6−1≤14j/6(s1/60−561/6−1),

and, since s0=Δ2/f,

s1/6j≤(Δ2)1/64j/6f1/6+561/6−1≤(Δ24jf)1/6+15.

Since

Δ24jf=(Δ2j)21f=(Δ2j−1)214f>(f1/ϵ′1+δ)214f=f2ϵ′−14(1+δ)2

can be made arbitrarily large by taking f sufficiently large, we see that

(Δ24jf)1/6+15≤(1+δ)1/3(Δ24jf)1/6.

Thus, sj≤((1+δ)Δ/2j)2/f, completing the proof.

Appendix D Proof of Corollary 3.3

We use the term “with high probability” to refer to probabilities that tend to 1 as n goes to infinity. Corollary 3.3 follows in a straightforward way from the following lemma.

Lemma D.1.

For any δ∈(0,1) there exists a constant d0 such that, for any d∈(d0lnn,(nlnn)13), each vertex of the random graph G=G(n,d/n) is contained in at most Δδ triangles with high probability, where Δ is the maximum degree of G.

Proof of Corollary 3.3.

According to [5], for a graph G∈G(n,d/n) we know that with high probability

χ(G)=12dlnd(1+o(1)). (50)

Fix ζ∈(0,1) and δ∈(0,2ζ1+2ζ). According to Lemma D.1, there exists a constant d0 such that for any d∈(d0lnn,(nlnn)13) each vertex of G=G(n,d/n) is contained in at most Δδ triangles with probability that tends to 1 as n goes to infinity. Thus, we can apply the sparse case of Theorem 3.2 with parameter ζ>0 since

f=Δ2Δδ>Δ2−2ζ1+2ζ(lnΔ)2,

for large enough Δ. This yields an upper bound q on the chromatic number of G that is at most

q = (1+ζ)Δln√f (51)
≤ (1+ζ)Δ1+ζ1+2ζlnΔ+lnlnΔ
≤ (1+2ζ)ΔlnΔ.

Moreover, since the expected degree of every vertex of G is d and its distribution is binomial with parameter dn, standard Chernoff bounds and the union bound imply that for any η∈(0,1), Δ≤(1+η)d with high probability, for large enough d0.

Combining the latter fact with (50) and (51), we deduce that we can find an arbitrarily small constant η′∈(0,1) such that

q≤(2+η′)χ(G)

by choosing ζ and η sufficiently small. Picking η′=4ϵ1−2ϵ we obtain χ(G)≥q2+η′≥q(12−ϵ), concluding the proof of Corollary 3.3. ∎

d.1 Proof of Lemma d.1

Let Δv be the random variable that equals the degree of vertex v of G. Observe that Δv∼Binom(n−1,dn) and, therefore, using a standard Chernoff bound and the fact that d≥d0logn we get that

Pr[Δv∉(1±110)d]≤1n2,

for large enough d0. Thus, by a union bound we get that Pr[Δ∈(1±110)d]≤1n.

Let Tv be the number of triangles that contain vertex v and B be the event that Δ∉(1±110)d. Then,

Pr[Tv>Δδ]≤Pr[Tv>Δδ∣¯¯¯¯B]+Pr[B]≤Pr[(Tv>Δδ)∩¯¯¯¯B]1−1n+1n.

Observe that Tv∼Binom((n−12),(dn)3) and E[Tv]≤d32n. Thus, for any fixed value of Δ∈(1±110)d, setting 1+β=Δδd3/2n and using a standard Chernoff bound we obtain:

Pr[Tv>Δδ]≤e−β2d3/2n3≤1n2

since

β ≥ ((1−110)d)δ−d3/2nd3/2n>0,
13β2d32n ≥ 13(((1−110)d)δ−d3/2n)2d3/2n≥2lnn,

whenever d∈[d0lnn,(nlnn)13] and for large enough n and d0. Taking a union bound over v concludes the proof of the lemma.
